box-breathing.title: Box breathing
box-breathing.subtitle: A square rhythm to steady attention.
box-breathing.summary: When thoughts feel rushed, a steady four-part breath can slow the pace.

how.title: How to use
steps: Begin when you are ready.
Follow the visual rhythm instead of counting.
Stay for a few cycles, or as long as feels right.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Box breathing uses four equal phases to steady your pace.
Even breathing signals safety to your nervous system.
A consistent rhythm helps ease mental spirals.

four-seven-eight.title: 4-7-8 breathing
four-seven-eight.subtitle: Lengthen the exhale to invite calm and sleepiness.
four-seven-eight.summary: A soothing cadence to quiet the body before rest.

how.title: How to use
steps: Sit comfortably or lie down if you are winding down.
Let the long exhale soften your shoulders and jaw.
Repeat for four to six rounds, then pause.

why.title: Why it helps
points: The extended exhale shifts your nervous system toward rest.
The gentle hold builds a sense of steadiness between breaths.
It can be especially helpful before sleep or during anxious moments.

coherent-breathing.title: Coherent breathing
coherent-breathing.subtitle: Six counts in, six counts out for steady focus.
coherent-breathing.summary: A calm rhythm that balances breath and attention.

how.title: How to use
steps: Breathe in for six counts, then out for six counts.
Keep the breath soft and smooth, like a gentle wave.
Stay for a few minutes, then return to your task.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Balanced breathing supports heart rhythm coherence.
A steady pace can improve attention and emotional steadiness.
It is an easy reset between tasks or meetings.

five-four-three-two-one.title: 5-4-3-2-1 grounding
five-four-three-two-one.subtitle: Name what you sense to return to the present.
five-four-three-two-one.summary: A sensory scan to anchor your attention here and now.

step1.prompt: Name 5 things you can see around you
step1.placeholder: The light on the wall, a book, my hands...

step2.placeholder: The chair beneath me, my breath, the floor...

step3.placeholder: Birds outside, my breathing, distant traffic...

completion.title: You are here. You are present.
completion.subtitle: Take a moment to notice how you feel now.

how.title: How to use
steps: Start when you are ready.
Notice each sense without judgment.
Move through the steps at your own pace.

why.title: Why it helps
points: The 5-4-3-2-1 method anchors you in the present moment.
Sensory attention interrupts racing thoughts and loops.
You do not have to change anything, just notice.

one-minute-mindful-break.title: One-minute mindful break
one-minute-mindful-break.subtitle: A brief pause to reset your attention.
one-minute-mindful-break.summary: Sixty seconds of stillness to clear mental fog.
one-minute-mindful-break.instruction: Close your eyes if comfortable. Feel your breath move in and out. Notice your body where it touches the chair or floor. Let thoughts pass without holding them. You have this minute.

completion.title: You paused. You returned.
completion.subtitle: Even one minute can shift your state.

how.title: How to use
steps: Find a quiet moment between tasks.
Close your eyes or soften your gaze.
Follow your breath for one full minute.

why.title: Why it helps
points: A brief pause can interrupt stress cycles.
One minute of focus improves decision-making.
Regular micro-breaks build lasting calm.

guided-visualization.title: Guided visualization
guided-visualization.subtitle: Imagine a place of calm and safety.
guided-visualization.summary: A mental journey to a peaceful scene.

beach.intro: Picture yourself on a warm beach. The sand is soft beneath you.
beach.sense1: Feel the sun warming your skin.
beach.sense2: Hear the gentle rhythm of waves.
beach.sense3: Smell the salt air. Taste it on your lips.
beach.sense4: Notice the space around you—open, safe, calm.
beach.closing: When you are ready, take a deep breath and return.

forest.intro: Imagine walking through a quiet forest. The path is soft with moss.
forest.sense1: Feel the cool air on your face.
forest.sense4: Notice the light filtering through the trees.
forest.closing: When you are ready, take a deep breath and return.

mountain.intro: Picture yourself standing on a mountain overlook. The view is endless.
mountain.sense1: Feel the breeze moving around you.
mountain.sense2: Hear the quiet hum of wind.
mountain.sense4: Notice the vastness—you are small, but you are here.
mountain.closing: When you are ready, take a deep breath and return.

completion.title: You went somewhere peaceful.
completion.subtitle: You can return whenever you need.

how.title: How to use
steps: Choose a scene that feels calming.
Close your eyes and follow the prompts.
Engage all your senses in the imagery.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Visualization triggers your relaxation response.
Mental imagery can lower heart rate and stress.
Creating a mental safe space builds resilience.

self-compassion-break.title: Self-compassion break
self-compassion-break.subtitle: Offer yourself the kindness you need.
self-compassion-break.summary: Three steps to respond to pain with care.

step1.title: Acknowledge the difficulty
step1.prompt: This is a moment of suffering.
step1.instruction: Place a hand on your heart if it feels right. Notice what you are feeling.

step2.title: Remember you are not alone
step2.prompt: Struggle is part of being human.
step2.instruction: Everyone experiences pain. You are not broken or uniquely flawed.

step3.title: Offer yourself kindness
step3.prompt: May I be kind to myself.
step3.instruction: Choose a phrase that feels supportive: 'May I be patient with myself.' 'May I give myself the compassion I need.'

completion.title: You met yourself with kindness.
completion.subtitle: This is the practice. Return to it when you need it.

how.title: How to use
steps: Use this when you are being hard on yourself.
Move through each of the three steps slowly.
Repeat the phrases silently or out loud.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Self-compassion reduces anxiety and self-criticism.
It activates the same calming response as receiving care.
You deserve the same kindness you give others.

positive-affirmations.title: Positive affirmations
positive-affirmations.subtitle: Gentle reminders of your capability.
positive-affirmations.summary: Short phrases to counter doubt and build confidence.

confidence: I trust myself to handle what comes.
I have the skills I need.
I am enough as I am.
calm: I am safe in this moment.
I breathe in peace, I release tension.
I do not have to rush.
My calm is a choice I can make.
growth: Mistakes are part of the path.
I am becoming who I want to be.
Progress is not always visible, but it is happening.
gratitude: I am grateful for this moment.
I notice the small gifts in my day.
I appreciate my body and what it does for me.
I have enough. I am enough.
I see the good around me.

positive-affirmations.instruction: Read this affirmation slowly. Let it settle. Repeat it a few times if it resonates.

completion.title: You planted seeds of belief.
completion.subtitle: Return to these phrases when doubt arises.

how.title: How to use
steps: Choose a category that speaks to your need.
Read each affirmation slowly, out loud or silently.
Repeat the ones that resonate most.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Affirmations rewire negative thought patterns.
Repetition builds new neural pathways.
They offer an alternative to harsh self-talk.

body-shake-release.title: Body shake and release
body-shake-release.subtitle: Move your body to release stuck energy.
body-shake-release.summary: A quick somatic reset to discharge tension.

instructions.start: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Take a breath.
instructions.hands: Shake out your hands and wrists.
instructions.arms: Let the shake move up your arms and shoulders.
instructions.body: Bounce gently on your knees. Let your whole body shake.
instructions.release: Continue for 30 seconds to 2 minutes. Let it be playful.

completion.title: You moved the energy.
completion.subtitle: Notice how your body feels now.

how.title: How to use
steps: Stand somewhere private if you feel self-conscious.
Let the movement be loose and uncontrolled.
Shake for at least 30 seconds, longer if it feels good.

why.title: Why it helps
points: Shaking mimics the body's natural stress discharge.
It releases muscle tension and stuck energy.
Movement resets your nervous system.

progressive-muscle-relaxation.title: Progressive muscle relaxation
progressive-muscle-relaxation.subtitle: Tense and release each part of your body.
progressive-muscle-relaxation.summary: A guided wind-down to ease into sleep.

bodyParts.name: Feet and toes
bodyParts.instruction: Curl your toes and tense your feet. Hold for 3 seconds. Release and notice the difference.

bodyParts.name: Calves
bodyParts.instruction: Tighten your calf muscles. Hold. Release and feel them soften.

bodyParts.name: Thighs
bodyParts.instruction: Tense your thighs. Hold. Let them go heavy and relaxed.

bodyParts.name: Glutes and hips
bodyParts.instruction: Squeeze your glutes. Hold. Release completely.

bodyParts.name: Abdomen
bodyParts.instruction: Pull your belly in tight. Hold. Let it soften and expand.

bodyParts.name: Hands and arms
bodyParts.instruction: Make fists and tighten your arms. Hold. Release and feel warmth spread.

bodyParts.name: Shoulders
bodyParts.instruction: Lift your shoulders toward your ears. Hold. Drop them and feel the tension melt.

bodyParts.name: Neck
bodyParts.instruction: Gently press your head back. Hold. Release and let your neck lengthen.

bodyParts.name: Face
bodyParts.instruction: Scrunch your face tight. Hold. Release and let your jaw drop open.

completion.title: Your body is relaxed.
completion.subtitle: Notice the heaviness, the warmth. Let yourself rest.

how.title: How to use
steps: Lie down or sit in a comfortable position.
Move through each body part slowly.
Tense for 3-5 seconds, then fully release.

why.title: Why it helps
points: PMR signals your body it is safe to rest.
It reduces physical tension that blocks sleep.
The structured focus quiets a racing mind.
